when the array is an array of object like String we get 
java.lang.ClassCastException
	at org.drools.base.evaluators.ObjectFactory$ObjectContainsEvaluator.evaluate(ObjectFactory.java:386)
	at org.drools.rule.LiteralRestriction.isAllowed(LiteralRestriction.java:61)
	at org.drools.rule.LiteralConstraint.isAllowed(LiteralConstraint.java:82)
	at org.drools.reteoo.AlphaNode.assertObject(AlphaNode.java:140)
	at org.drools.reteoo.CompositeObjectSinkAdapter.propagateAssertObject(CompositeObjectSinkAdapter.java:317)
	at org.drools.reteoo.ObjectTypeNode.assertObject(ObjectTypeNode.java:183)
	at org.drools.reteoo.Rete.assertObject(Rete.java:121)
	at org.drools.reteoo.ReteooRuleBase.assertObject(ReteooRuleBase.java:196)
	at org.drools.reteoo.ReteooWorkingMemory.doAssertObject(ReteooWorkingMemory.java:70)
	at org.drools.common.AbstractWorkingMemory.assertObject(AbstractWorkingMemory.java:727)
	at org.drools.common.AbstractWorkingMemory.assertObject(AbstractWorkingMemory.java:551)

example: assume we have a class message
class Message{
   String [] mess;
}

rule "test"
when 
   Message(mess contains "HELLO")
then 
..
end 
the reason is the test in the org.drools.base.ValueType class
else if ( clazz.isAssignableFrom( Object[].class ) ) {
            return ValueType.ARRAY_TYPE; the test will be satisfied only for array of java.lang.Object and not for others object
a simple solution is to modify this test in 
else if ( clazz.isArray() && clazz.getComponentType() instanceof Object) {
            return ValueType.ARRAY_TYPE;

column3:
jbossrules\drools-core\src\main\java\org\drools ase\evaluators\BigIntegerFactory.java and BigIntegerFactory.java
won't compile in 1.5 source because BigDecimal isn't a 100% backwards compatible from java 1.5 to 1.4,
due to them generifying it.

The fix is easy: just add some casts, the JVM does this at runtime anyway.

For example:
            final BigDecimal comp = (BigDecimal) extractor.getValue( object1 );
            return comp.compareTo( object2.getValue() ) < 0;
This code turns red in java source=1.5 in IntelliJ IDEA  (and in Eclipse I would expect the same?)

Turn it into:
            ...
            return comp.compareTo( (BigDecimal) object2.getValue() ) < 0;

I didn't create a patch as it's fast to fix: just copy-paste (BigDecimal) in the 2 classes's use of the compareTo method.
column4: BigDecimalFactory and BigIntegerFactory don't compile with java 1.5 source

column3:
At present, no-loop is simply limited to stopping a rule firing itself with the same facts.

A common request I get, whenever visiting anyone, is how to remember all rule activations (rule/fact combinations that have fired in the past) and stop the same happening in the future in a single instance of working memory.

This can be an option set on a per instance, or per haps per-file basis. By default it must be off, as it will require extra memory to record the history, and I don't think it would be suitable for long lived working memories.

However, for the pseudo "stateless" pattern (which probably 70-80% of people use) it would be quite safe and beneficial.
column4: Enhance no-loop functionality

column3:
Runtime deployment utility it a component which is deployed where the rule engine executions.

Its features:

* Pull a ruleset (or collection of) from a Repository, build and cache

This is done, and is in drools-repository/runtime-deployer (the svn plug in is next to it)

column3: The KIE workbench editors being hosted in Eclipse will require a Data Model Oracle (DMO) which is comprised of all the resources contained in a project, compiled into an in-memory representation. Therefore, constructors for all of the necessary beans must be exposed to allow "manual" construction.

The expected behavior is:

* Otherwise, once removing a node, any incoming and outgoing connectors must be removed rather than just loosing the connections.

column3:
With increasing number of available classes it's harder and harder to define type of a data object field.

The most common types (String, Integer, Double, Boolean) are mixed with others which makes it difficult to find them.

Business users might not understand the types as String, Integer, Double or Boolean - we might introduce a simplified set of the common types as Text, Number, Real number, Truth value or similarly.

Dropdown ordering is quite weird, not alphabetized, mixed case, ... which is confusing to the end-user.

It might be interesting to split the types into categories because usually there are 20+ types - simple types, custom types, data objects, Java types, ...
column4: Improve experience of defining data object field type

column3:
Support process migration from one runtime manager to another.

The current jbpm api call could migrate a process running in one runtime manager(context).  In a situation when trying to migrate a process running in runtime manager A to a different B, it does't work.  This RFE is seeking the support to migrate the process running in one runtime manager to another.
The use case that drives this RFE is that users deploy a kjar with one releaseid and load it to a kiesession. They deploy a newer version of kjar later and load it to a new kieSession with the new release id. They would like to migrate the processes running in the old kiesession to the ones running in the new kiesession.
column4: Support process migration from one runtime manager to another.

column3:
Currently the runtime REST API requests are blocking I/O, which means that it holds the connection until the server side processing is done.

A good example is the process start action. Even using a command to start a process in the /execute endpoint, it holds the execution until the process is finished.

Although this feature MAY include other endpoints, notice that the start process feature is the most problematic one, since it waits the process reach a safe point to return the process instance to the client.

Another important point is that even with the new asynchronous task feature introduced in BPM Suite 6.2 may help in this matter, but it is not the best solution, since most cases the processes are modeled by business analysts, who could not be aware of the need of using async tasks.

This is a RFE to allow a better handling of such cases. A solution like the JOBS approach used in Guvnor REST seems reasonable.

UPDATE:

Even the Remote JMS API is not async, so this is also a feature to make the remote Java JMS API behave asynchronously. 

4. Why does the customer need this? (List the business requirements here)

The long running process holds the client thread and even if we execute the call in an asynchronous thread, this will not solve the problem, since the original call will be blocked waiting for a server  response, it is also a subject for timeouts.

5. How would the customer like to achieve this? (List the functional requirements here)

Allowing the fire and forget feature. The implementation could look like the use of the JMS API works today.

If used manually, the JMS API can be used to send a message to start a process and the client can continue its execution without having to wait an update from the server.

An update also must be done in the remote Java JMS API. Currently it got stuck waiting the server to post a message with the response of the start process command. This could be configured through a flag. If the flag is true, the fired messages in actions like start a process will just be sent the client will not wait for a response to consume it, and the client could read the generated process instance id in a different way.

6. For each functional requirement listed, specify how Red Hat and the customer can test to confirm the requirement is successfully implemented.

- Start a long running process using the REST API and the response should be immediate.
column4: Allow "fire and forget" feature in runtime Kie Server Remote APIs

Issue:
The description of terminating end event is wrong. (http://docs.jboss.org/jbpm/v5.4/userguide/ch.core-basics.html#d0e1465). It says "Note that, if you use a terminating event node inside a sub-process, you are terminating the top-level process instance, not just that sub-process.", contrary to the BPMN2.0 spec (source https://community.jboss.org/message/779138 or https://issues.jboss.org/browse/JBPM-3371).

What to be expected:
A changement of the description like  "Note that, if you use a terminating event node inside a sub-process, you are terminating just that sub-process, not the top-level process instance."
column4: Description wrong about terminating end event and sub-process.

column3:
It boils down to the fact that when {{((AsyncTaskServiceWrapper) TaskService).skip()}} is called, this initiates a chain of events in which the sever thread and the client thread fire off methods which just send more messages back and forth. 

1. The process sends a message to the server thread via AsyncTaskServiceWrapper.skip()
2. The server receives the message and sends a message to the service to remove a task (TaskServerHandler, l.88)
3. The service receives a message -- and fires one immediately back.. (AsyncTaskServiceWrapper.getTask(), l.291
4. In the mean time, the server has already moved on to sending the results to the server (TaskServerHandler, l.89)

I'll fill the exactly logic of this in later..
column4: Race condition in Human Task service: ((AsyncTaskServiceWrapper) TaskService).skip

column3:
The user configures email like this:
{code}
<string name="jbpm.mail.smtp.host" value="mail.xxx.int" />
<bean name="jbpm.mail.address.resolver" class="org.jbpm.identity.mail.IdentityAddressResolver" singleton="true" />
<string name="jbpm.mail.from.address" value="xxxsoa@yyynetwork.it" />
<string name="jbpm.mail.user" value="xxxsoa@yyynetwork.it" />
<string name="jbpm.mail.pass" value="xxxxxxx" />
<string name="jbpm.mail.port" value="25" />
<string name="jbpm.mail.smtp.auth" value="true" />
<string name="jbpm.mail.debug" value="false" />
{code}

Then they use an Email node in their process.

For recipients on the domain 'yyynetwork.it', there is no problem. (This domain doesn't require authentication.) But if the recipient is on some other domain, they get this Exception: "Caused by: com.sun.mail.smtp.SMTPAddressFailedException: 554 5.7.1 <some.person@someplace.com>: Relay access denied"

----

It is suspected that this is similar to an issue addressed in jBPM-3032. Here, the suggested fix is to use javax.mail.PasswordAuthentication. That may be what's required here, as well.
column4: jBPM Mail Node does not authenticate, results in "Relay access denied" when recipient is not on local server

column3:
Method setPooledActors(String... actorIds) of TaskInstance and SwimlaneInstance uses PooledActor.createPool(String[] actorIds, ...) method. 

This method creates new instances of PooledActor and associates them to a taskInstance or swimlaneInstance, and therefore it always inserts new registers in table JBPM_POOLEDACTOR. However, method setPooledActors(Set<PooledActor> pooledActors) of the classes mentioned above associates directly the taskInstance or swimlaneInstance to the pooledActors, reusing them.

If method createPool were able to find existing pooled actors for the given actors (String[] actorIds parameter), it would be possible to reuse them, creating only the nonexisting pooled actors. In order to ensure it, a constraint unique (ACTORID_, SWIMLANEINSTANCE_) in table JBPM_POOLEDACTOR can be added to the database scripts.
column4: Method PooledActor.createPool(String[] actorIds, ...) always creates new pooled actors and doesn't reuse existing ones.

column3:
There is a named query "ProcessInstancesWaitingForEvent" that lives in a drools persistence jar under "META-INF/orm.xml". 

The problem is not even that the query is wrong ( org.hibernate.QueryException: cannot dereference scalar collection element.. ), but that majority of applications that sit on top of JPA rely on its own mappings, and hence this query either:
 
   1. Lost, since the custom "persistence.xml" will redefine the path to other mapping files

   2. Will result in "Duplicate query mapping" exception if defined in a custom mapping file ( http://opensource.atlassian.com/projects/hibernate/browse/HHH-4152 )

Would be more logical not to depend that everyone knows to look inside "drools persistence jar", and to have an extensive documentation explaining "ProcessInstancesWaitingForEvent". It maybe hardcoded through @NamedQuery or just be available as an OPTIONAL file to use by Drools clients: e.g. "<mapping-file>META-INF/persistence/mapping/drools/drools-named-queries.xml</mapping-file>" ( and again: documented.. )

/Anatoly
column4: Drools Persistence Should Not Rely on an Existing Named Query in "META-INF/orm.xml"

column3:
"ProcessInstancesWaitingForEvent" query that is used after each process / subprocess ends is extremely inefficient, and since there is no way to force an INDEX without being coupled with JPA provider, this query execution time increase exponentially as the number of processes goes up. Currently with only 20000 processes, the query takes 18(!!!) seconds to execute:

<named-query name="ProcessInstancesWaitingForEvent">
    <query>
        SELECT processInstanceInfo.processInstanceId
        FROM ProcessInstanceInfo processInstanceInfo
        WHERE :type in elements ( processInstanceInfo.eventTypes )
    </query>
</named-query> 

It is inefficient not only because there is no INDEX enforced, but because it goes into the sub query for no good reason. The better/correct query is:

SELECT processInstanceInfo.processInstanceId
FROM ProcessInstanceInfo processInstanceInfo, EventTypes eventTypes
WHERE eventTypes.element = :type
AND processInstanceInfo.processInstanceId = eventTypes.processInstanceId 

In order to get to this "better" query, since it is a JPA one, an EventType/s entity should be created ( it does not currently exist in 5.1.1 ).

/Anatoly
column4: ProcessInstancesWaitingForEvent Query is Extremely Inefficient and Should Be Simplified

column3:
Hi, guys. 

I'm doing some translating work of 《jBPM User Guide》, and I mentioned that in Table 6.21, Section 6.2.7, there are some descriptions about the 'outcome-value'.

Table 6.21. Extra transition elements in case of outcome variable mappings:
=======================================================
    Element: outcome-value 
    Multiplicity: 0..1
    Description: If the outcome matches the value, this transition is taken after the sub-process ended. The value is specified with one child element.
=======================================================

But there's no example provided indeed.

Section 6.2.7.2 of 《jBPM User Guide》 shows an example about the outcome variable:
===============================================================
    <sub-process name="review" sub-process-key="SubProcessReview" outcome="#{result}">
        <transition name="ok" to="next step" />
        <transition name="nok" to="update" />
        <transition name="reject" to="close" />
    </sub-process>
===============================================================

I tried to midify it to:
==============
    <sub-process name="review" outcome="#{result}" sub-process-key="SubProcessReview">            
        <transition name="ok" to="next step">
            <outcome-value>
                <int value="3"/>
            </outcome-value>
        </transition>
        <transition name="nok" to="update"/>
        <transition name="reject" to="close"/>
    </sub-process>
==============

But I got org.hibernate.exception.ConstraintViolationException and java.sql.SQLException after: 
======================================================================
    Map<String, Object> variables = new HashMap<String, Object>();
    variables.put("result", 3);
    taskService.setVariables(task.getId(), variables);
    taskService.completeTask(task.getId());
======================================================================

I don't know whether it's a bug or just I do it a wrong way.

Please tell me the usage of the 'outcome-value'  of sub-process. Examples better.

Thanks. Regards from China~
column4: the 'outcome-value' feature of sub-process does not work

column3:
When an execution is signalled, the task belonging to that execution becomes unusable. It is made 'not-signalling', has no exection (thus cannot be ended, which you would not want to) but it keeps showing up in the tasklist.... 

Proposed solution is to have an additional task state (like the 'timeout' that is introduced). If an execution is signalled, the task is 'cancelled' this is something completely different then it being completed or any other state....

The behaviour of which transition will be taken will not be different from what it is now.... A warning will be logged that a execution is signalled and it would be better to act on the task itself...

Subtasks will/should be treated the same.
column4: A task is put in an unusable state if the execution it belongs to is signalled

When calling repositoryService.deleteDeployment(deploymentId); I get the following sql syntax error:

"Unknown column 'myprocess' in 'where clause'"

This is the sql statement that gets executed:
select deployment1_.OBJNAME_ as col_0_0_, deployment1_.DEPLOYMENT_ as col_1_0_
from JBPM4_DEPLOYMENT deployment0_, JBPM4_DEPLOYPROP deployment1_, JBPM4_DEPLOYPROP deployment2_, JBPM4_DEPLOYPROP deployment3_
where deployment1_.KEY_='pdid'
and deployment1_.DEPLOYMENT_=deployment0_.DBID_
and deployment2_.KEY_='pdkey'
and deployment2_.OBJNAME_=deployment1_.OBJNAME_
and deployment2_.DEPLOYMENT_=deployment0_.DBID_
and deployment3_.KEY_='pdversion'
and deployment3_.OBJNAME_=deployment1_.OBJNAME_
and deployment3_.DEPLOYMENT_=deployment0_.DBID_
and deployment1_.DEPLOYMENT_=myprocess-4

There should be quotes around myprocess-4 to fix the sql statement 

=>

see ProcessDefinitionQueryImpl: 
if (deploymentId!=null) {
      appendWhereClause("idProperty.deployment.dbid = "+deploymentId+" ", hql);
}

should be (imho)

if (deploymentId!=null) {
      appendWhereClause("idProperty.deployment.dbid = '"+deploymentId+"' ", hql);
}

column3:
When a process definition is read and when it contains a decision named with a "/" character, a NullPointerException is raised:

	import org.jbpm.graph.def.ProcessDefinition;
	public class TestDecisionNPE {
		  public static final void main(String[] args){
			    ProcessDefinition.parseXmlString(
			      "<process-definition>" +
			      "  <start-state>" +
			      "    <transition to='d/e' />" +
			      "  </start-state>" +      
			      "  <decision name='d/e'>" +
			      "    <transition name='one' to='a'>" +
			      "      <condition>#{a == 1}</condition>" +
			      "    </transition>" +
			      "    <transition name='three' to='c'>" +
			      "      <condition>#{a == 3}</condition>" +
			      "    </transition>" +
			      "  </decision>" +
			      "  <state name='a' />" +
			      "  <state name='c' />" +      
			      "</process-definition>");
			  }
	}

raises:

GRAVE: couldn't parse process definition
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.jbpm.graph.def.ProcessDefinition.findNode(ProcessDefinition.java:345)
	at org.jbpm.graph.def.ProcessDefinition.findNode(ProcessDefinition.java:299)
	at org.jbpm.jpdl.xml.JpdlXmlReader.resolveTransitionDestination(JpdlXmlReader.java:774)
	at org.jbpm.jpdl.xml.JpdlXmlReader.resolveTransitionDestinations(JpdlXmlReader.java:740)
	at org.jbpm.jpdl.xml.JpdlXmlReader.resolveTransitionDestinations(JpdlXmlReader.java:732)
	at org.jbpm.jpdl.xml.JpdlXmlReader.readProcessDefinition(JpdlXmlReader.java:162)
	at org.jbpm.graph.def.ProcessDefinition.parseXmlString(ProcessDefinition.java:151)
	at test.TestDecisionNPE.main(TestDecisionNPE.java:7)
Exception in thread "main" org.jbpm.jpdl.JpdlException: [[ERROR] couldn't parse process definition]
	at org.jbpm.jpdl.xml.JpdlXmlReader.readProcessDefinition(JpdlXmlReader.java:172)
	at org.jbpm.graph.def.ProcessDefinition.parseXmlString(ProcessDefinition.java:151)
	at test.TestDecisionNPE.main(TestDecisionNPE.java:7)

This is due to a "node = nodeCollection.getNode(namePart);" in ProcessDefinition.findNode(): a Decision has no nodes, so the nodeCollection is null.

It should be :
1. a more descriptive exception message, such as "could not get the node with name XXX"
2. a validation step which prevent the node name to contain "/" characters, e.g. throw an exception "the node name cannot contain a "/" character"
column4: NPE when reading a process definition with a decision name which contains the "/" character

column3: Using an end-state in a leg of fork does not end the process. It ends the token (and parent tokens if it was the last active child). If one really wants to end the full process, the end-complete-process attribute should be used on the end-state. This is not documented anywhere, but it should.
column4: document 'end-complete-process' attribute on end-state

column3:
In "/jbpm.3/jpdl/userguide/en/modules/persistence.xml" (CVS version 1.11), the "Managed transactions" section describe the most important configuration property from the "hibernate.cfg.xml" file as follow:
"hibernate.connection.datasource=  --datasource JNDI name-- like e.g. java:/DefaultDS"

This property should be described using a XML format because the "hibernate.cfg.xml" in in XML format, for example:
    <property name="hibernate.connection.datasource"> --datasource JNDI name-- like e.g. java:/DefaultDS </property>
	
Note: not tested on the german documentation.
column4: Bad property format of hibernate.cfg.xml snippet in the user guide "Persistence" chapter

column3:
The JBPM 3.2.2 user guide refers to the file "jbpm.properties", which was replaced by "jbpm.cfg.xml" in version JBPM 3.1 (see http://sourceforge.net/project/shownotes.php?release_id=383725&group_id=70542 ).
While references to "jbpm.properties" may be valid in a change log or a migration guide, they are not valid in the following files.

/jbpm.3/jpdl/userguide/en/modules/persistence.xml (CVS version 1.11):
In the sentence "Note that the hibernate configuration file resource is mapped in the property 'jbpm.hibernate.cfg.xml' and can be customized in the jbpm.cfg.xml", the "jbpm.hibernate.cfg.xml" property name should be replaced by "resource.hibernate.cfg.xml" (i.e. the property of the file snippet shown just below that sentence).


/jbpm.3/jpdl/userguide/en/modules/configuration.xml (CVS version 1.7):
The sentence
    "Location: <literal>hibernate.cfg.xml</literal> unless specified otherwise in the jbpm.hibernate.cfg.xml property in the jbpm.properties file."
should be replaced by:
    "Location: <literal>hibernate.cfg.xml</literal> unless specified otherwise in the resource.hibernate.cfg.xml property in the jbpm.cfg.xml file."
column4: Bad references to property "jbpm.hibernate.cfg.xml" from the "jbpm.properties" file removed in JBPM 3.1

column3:
Businesses often want a "super manager" to have the ability to see and work on the tasks of all users.  With the current jBPM, it is very difficult to generate a list of all TaskInstances.

The feature requested is a method for listing all TaskInstances regardless of user.  It appears to be a simple variation on the current methods which request TaskInstances by ActorId or an array of ActorIds.

One possibility might be to modify the query used by TaskManagementSession.findTaskInstances(String actorId) to use the SQL "LIKE" operator instead of "=" so that the % wildcard could be used to retrieve all TaskInstances.  I don't know if that is portable to all databases; it works well for Oracle.

It has been suggested that this feature can be created as custom code, but custom code becomes very expensive to maintain and integrate with new releases of jBPM for small development companies like ours.

A similar feature to retrieve all ProcessInstances regardless of ProcessDefinition would also be highly useful for similar reasons.

A criticism is that the method would introduce scalability / performance problems.  That is always an issue that is difficult to avoid completely depending on the application.  For example, a business that has thousands of workers all performing the same workflow could generate a very large list using "GraphSession.findProcessInstances(long processDefinitionId)" which would be on the same order as a hypothetical "TaskManagementSession.getAllTaskInstances()" for that particular application.
column4: getAllTaskInstances(), getAllProcessInstances()

column3:
change the hibernate mapping technique from *.hbm.xml to annotations. That includes:
- Change attribute mapping to getter/setter mapping. That implicates to provide the possibility to invoke a setter with a null value (jboss as is doing that) e.g. TaskInstance.setTask()
- Collection mapping with generic datatypes (jdk5) - that enables reflection on the data structure
- Changing the inheritance of persist classes e.g. an abstract basic class that provides the getter/setter for id and name (name schould be abstract)
- Clean up mapped properties e.g. the method getId() is implemented twice in classes GraphElement and TaskNode
- Providing test cases
column4: EJB3 support with annotations / simplify db schema

column3: The current phase listener closes the context after the render response (6) phase.  However sometimes the response is complete before this phase is arrived at, so close will never be called.\n\nThe fix is to check the "response complete" flag in the JSF FacesContext in the afterPhase method.
column4: Leaking database connections due to context not closing on some pages

column3:
Release of JDBC connections changed with hibernate version > 3.0.
DbPersistenceService now throws exception when trying to close a hibernate session (because in was closed automatically when the transaction committed).
The exception happens every few seconds when using the jbpm scheduler-service.
See below for stack trace.

See http://www.hibernate.org/250.html#A31 for a detailed description of hibernate-changes regarding JDBC connections.

FYI: The exception does not roll back the transaction, because it has already been committed. 
Please adapt the code to the new hibernate behaviour. Maybe just comment out the "throw" of the exception.
I have no idea what code would work with old _and_ new hibernate versions.
We just got the problem integrating jbpm into a jboss AS 4.0.4 using hibernate 3.2.

column3:
To build jBPM successfully, I had to make the following changes.

A. Add the constructs to create missing directories under target "download-eclipse" in jbpm.dist uild.xml

  <mkdir dir="${local-repository}/${eclipse-folder}"/>
  <mkdir dir="${local-repository}/${webtools-folder}"/>
  <mkdir dir="${local-repository}/${emf-folder}"/>
  <mkdir dir="${local-repository}/${gef-folder}"/>
  <mkdir dir="${local-repository}/${jem-folder}"/>

B. Modify the <import file > under jbpm.dist uild\projects\docs\gpd.userguide as 
  <import file="../../docbook-support/support.xml" />

Can you check in these changes in CVS? I am not sure if you are the right person.

Thanks,
Prabhat
column4: build.xml needs to be modified for jbpm to build successfully

column3: In header2.jsp, for the left navigation links, the HTML anchor tag's href doesn't include the prefix "faces/" which is required to invoke the faces servlet, and therefore the pages fail.

column3: This is a fairly trivial request, but make the port number of the JBoss installation a configuration property, rather than hardcoding it in the build.deploy.xml file. Its kind of a nuisance to have to change these manually on all the deploy targets. Thx.
column4: Change ant build scripts in starter kit to make the JBoss HTTP port number as a property instead of hardcoded.

column3: For example, context.getGraphSession( ).loadProcessInstance uses a hiberate session.load to retrieve the instance.  This method does not indicate if the entity is not found in the database.  Hibernate documentation suggests using the get( ) method instead.\n\nWe need to make sure that the user can tell when entity is not found.  This applies to all of the entity loading in the core engine.
column4: Change "load" methods to indicate when an entity is "not found"

column3: When all of the tests are run through ant test or running the tests in eclipse (AllTests), some of the tests near the end fail with an out of memory error.  JProfiler shows that a steady of use of unreleased memory grows.  \n\nWe suspect that objects are not being released in the teardown() as they should since JUnit does not release any of test tests until the end of execution.
column4: Memory leak in DbTests

column3: The processstart api has no option of accepting variables. This way you cannot use them in the process-start event. This fires when it is started, before you can set any variables. Be passing e.g. a map of variables to the process start this becomes possible.
column4: have process start accept a map of variables

column4: scope of nodes in process definition mixed with superstates does not work

column3: When persisting a process definition with superstates and reloading, hibernate has trouble loading "root" nodes mixed with superstates. The superstate 'overwrites' the link. This is due to the re-use of the collectionindex column for both nodes within superstates, and nodes within process definition, and the fact that EVERY node has a link to the process definition.
column4: persisting process definition with superstate hibernate problems

column3:
I'm storing instances of java.util.Collection as process variables.  The first step I store a collection works fine.
Subsequent workflow steps generate a hibernate error when trying to save the process instance:
ERROR [JbpmSession] org.hibernate.HibernateException: Found shared references to a collection.

Here is a sample processDefinition.xml file:
========================================
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<process-definition name="collectionBug">
   <start-state name="start">
      <transition name="toEnterConApplication" to="enterConApplication"></transition>
   </start-state>
   <task-node name="enterConApplication">
      <task name="dataEntry" blocking="true">
         <assignment expression="group(DataEntry)-->member(member)"/>
         <controller>
            <variable name="conId" access="write,required" />
            <variable name="contacts" access="write,required" />
         </controller>
      </task>
      <transition name="toEvaluateCompleteness" to="evaluateCompleteness"></transition>
   </task-node>
   <task-node name="evaluateCompleteness">
      <task name="evaluate" blocking="true">
         <assignment expression="group(DataEntry)-->member(member)"/>
         <controller>
            <variable name="conId" access="read" />
            <variable name="contacts" access="read" />
         </controller>
      </task>
      <transition name="toEnd" to="End"></transition>
   </task-node>
   <end-state name="End"></end-state>
</process-definition>

=========================


Here is the user code (the error happens on the saveProcessInstance call):
=============================
public Long completeTaskInstance( String actorId, String taskInstanceId,
         Map vars, String transition ) throws TaskInstanceNotFoundException,
         WorkflowServiceException, BusinessValidationException
   {
      Long nextTaskId = null;

      final JbpmSession jbpmSession = jbpmSessionFactory.openJbpmSession();
      try
      {
         JbpmDefaultAuthenticator.pushAuthenticatedActorId(actorId);
         jbpmSession.beginTransaction();
         final org.jbpm.taskmgmt.exe.TaskInstance jbpmTaskInstance = jbpmSession
               .getTaskMgmtSession().loadTaskInstance(
                     Long.parseLong(taskInstanceId));

         if ( jbpmTaskInstance == null )
         {
            throw new TaskInstanceNotFoundException(
                  "Could not find jBPM TaskInstance: " + taskInstanceId);
         }

         if ( vars == null )
         {
            vars = new Hashtable();
         }

         if ( actorId == null )
            vars.remove("actorId");
         else
            vars.put("actorId", actorId);

         for ( final Iterator i = vars.keySet().iterator(); i.hasNext(); )
         {
            final String var = (String)i.next();
            Object obj = vars.get(var);
            jbpmTaskInstance.getToken().getProcessInstance()
                  .getContextInstance().setVariable(var, obj);
         }

         Node preTransitionNode = jbpmTaskInstance.getToken().getNode();
         // Token preTransitionToken = jbpmTaskInstance.getToken();
         Node goalNode = null;

         if ( transition == null )
         {
            goalNode = preTransitionNode.getDefaultLeavingTransition().getTo();
            jbpmTaskInstance.end();
         }
         else
         {
            goalNode = preTransitionNode.getLeavingTransition(transition)
                  .getTo();
            jbpmTaskInstance.end(transition);
         }

         jbpmSession.getGraphSession().saveProcessInstance(
               jbpmTaskInstance.getToken().getProcessInstance());
         jbpmSession.commitTransaction();

         // Determine if the next "task" is for the same actor
         nextTaskId = sameTaskActor(jbpmSession, actorId, goalNode,
               jbpmTaskInstance.getToken().getProcessInstance());

         return nextTaskId;
      }
      catch (Exception ex)
      {
         jbpmSession.rollbackTransaction();
         if ( ex instanceof DelegationException )
         {
            if ( ex.getCause() instanceof WorkflowServiceException )
            {
               // Throwable throwable = ex.getCause();
               throw (WorkflowServiceException)ex.getCause();
            }
            else
            {
               throw new WorkflowServiceException(ex.getCause().getMessage());
            }
         }
         throw new WorkflowServiceException("Unexpected exception received:",
               ex);
      }
      catch (Throwable e)
      {
         // Make sure you at least attempt to roll back the
         // transaction no matter what error or exception occurs.
         jbpmSession.rollbackTransaction();
         throw new Error(e);
      }
      finally
      {
         if ( jbpmSession != null )
         {
            jbpmSession.close();
         }
         JbpmDefaultAuthenticator.popAuthenticatedActorId();
      }
   }
===========================

column3:
Can be repeated with the following steps

        // Create an execution of the process definition.
        ProcessInstance processInstance = 
            new ProcessInstance(processDefinition)
column4: \n        Token token = processInstance.getRootToken()

column3: TaskInstance class has no getter and setter methods for the description property.\n\nNote: TaskInstance initially gets its description from Task.description and that should remain the default, but there must also be a way to read and change the description.
column4: add getter and setter for TaskInstance.description

column3: When a process is deployed its deployment date and activation date (when it can be used) should be saved. Later on i can get a process definition using its deployment/activation date.
column4: Addition of deployment date and getting a process definition using its deployment date

column3:
If you are processing the task-end event on a task (probably task-start as well), you do not have access to the taskInstance therefore you can not get the ActorId.

The following code in TaskInstance.end() :

     ExecutionContext executionContext = new ExecutionContext(token);
      task.fireEvent(Event.EVENTTYPE_TASK_END, executionContext);

needs to be changed to:

      ExecutionContext executionContext = new ExecutionContext(token);
      executionContext.setTask(task);
      executionContext.setTaskInstance(this);
      task.fireEvent(Event.EVENTTYPE_TASK_END, executionContext);

Without this fix, I would have to set the ActorId as a workflow variable so I could get access to it in my action handler....which would be really lame.

Basically, I can not call   ctx.getTaskInstance().getActorId() in my ActionHandler because getTaskInstance is null.

Here's a process definition example:

   <task-node name="myNode">
      <task name="myTask" blocking="true">
         <assignment expression="group(myGroup)-->member(member)"/>
         <controller>
            <variable name="myVariable" access="write,required" />
         </controller>
         <event type="task-end">
            <action name="MyAction" class="com.mycompany.MyAction" /> 
         </event>
      </task>
      <transition name="myTransition" to="myNextNode"></transition>
   </task-node>
column4: End-Task/Start-Task Event does not have access to the task instance.  Can not get actor id.

column3:
SchedulerMain.main throws NullPointerException at line 29

I think the order of the two lines are wrong:
    // register the console listener
    scheduler.getSchedulerThread().addListener(new LogListener())
column4:
// start the scheduler
    scheduler.start()
Propertys from inherited Actions not directly accessiblly

column3:
If we declare a action class in jBPM:
    <transition name="xxxx">
	<action class="com.camunda.ccs.process.orderprocessing.OrderActions$PrintReceipts"/>
    </transition>

And this class doesn't exist the follwoing exception is thrown:

Caused by: java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.jbpm.graph.def.Action.execute(Action.java:79)
	at org.jbpm.graph.def.GraphElement.executeActions(GraphElement.java:186)
	... 26 more

I think, it would be much better to have a ClassNotFoundException!
column4: Do not throw NullPointerException if delegation class is unknown
\n    }\n

column3:
JbpmSession javadocs say:

"represents the connection to the jbpm database.

 * You can obtain a DbSession with ..."

It looks like JbpmSession used to be called DbSession but the Javadoc was not updated when the class was renamed.
column4: Update JbpmSession javadocs

column3: Not everybody speaks dutch
column4: I18N for the webapp

column3:
The transitions are not displayed in the taskforms. This is due to the fact that jstl (c:foreach) and jsf (h:commandButton) can not be combined. Another solution has to be found. 

I investigated this and found an oracle jsf set of faces (adf) which do the job, so now it works. But I'm not sure if this should be the way to go. 4MB of libs, look and feel is slightly different and the buttons certainly are. I'll look into this a little further, but no solution at hand for now. 

Any suggestions?

Ronald
column4: transitions should be automatically displayed in the default webui

column3: The end-state node class should override the #read( ) method and only parse the attribute name, all event tags, and all exception-handler tags.  Currently it defaults to plain node behavior which does not match the schema or documentation.\n\nTom's review:  "only allowing attribute name and sub-elements "event" and "exception-handler" sounds reasonable to me."
column4: End-state parsing needs to be restricted

column3: In parsing the <task> and <start-state> elements, the XML reader should generate a problem warning if it cannot find the swimlane reference.  Currently #getSwimlane( ) has no error checking if it fails.  This does not cause a graph runtime error, but it is most likely not what the author intended.\n\n
column4: add warning to task, start-state if swimlane reference not found

column3: Please allow the <variable> element allow "any" schema content just like the "handlers".  This would allow the user to store custom metadata for their purposes.  This data should be persisted to the database and the API should allow its retrieval just like <action>, <assignment>, and <decision>/<handler>, etc.\n\nWe intend on using this to assist with driving the user interface from the work flow engine.  One type of meta data we need is the "java type" for the variable.
column4: Allow <variable> to have "any" content for user metadata

column3: process developers should be able to override the auto-generated flat-list form by writing a JSP.  the JSP is the content of the form and the JSP should be able to access the task parameters that are fetched from the task controller.\n\nthe link between the JSP-forms and the tasks should be added in a separate XML file
column4: specify custom task form-content based on a JSP

column3: Users are intended to throw exceptions from their action handlers in order to end processing that is "undoable".  Currently the core logs this as a SEVERE error and dumps a stacktrace.  This should be considered "business as usual" and at most logged as INFO.
column4: User thrown exceptions in ActionHandler logs severe error

column3:
A description element was supported in 2.0.  This does not exist in 3.0 so far.
We need to decide whether it should go in and to what extent. In 2.0 it was available on every major element.  I would like to suggest that we support it only on the process-definition itself, as people can use <! xxx ---> style comments anywhere they choose.

Perhaps this needs to be coordinated with tasks surrounding features for versioning, etc.
column4: Add <description> back into jPDL

column3: Develop an XML schema and corresponding DTD for the jPDL process-definition based on chapter 13 of the version 3.0 document.
column4: Create XSD/DTD for jPDL version 3.0

column3:
add a property to the process state xml information to indicate that binding of the subprocess should be done at deployment time in case only a name is specified.  e.g.

<process-state name="mysubprocess" version="latest">
 ...
</process-state>
column4: process-state deployment binding option

column3: initial persistence for \n1) definition: process and activities\n2) instance: links, variables, correlations, partnerlinks
column4: create initial persistence for bpel definition and instance classes

column3: removed the automatic supermagical bidirectional relations management.  now bidirectional relations management is done on the many-side of many-to-one relations. (much easier to understand)
column4: remove bidirectional relations management

column3: now jbpm uses a naming strategy and it's impossible to prevent the application of this naming strategy onto user mappings if they are added to the jbpm session.\n\nthe solution is to remove the jbpm naming strategy and specify the table and column names in the hibernate mapping files.
column4: remove the naming strategy

column3: event propagation might become a bottleneck in high-throughput deployments.\nthe easiest way to solve this is by introducing a configuration property that overrides the default behaviour of event propagation.  the current default is that event propagation is active.
column4: make event propagation configurable

column3: when users want to extend jbpm with their custom modules, we should also support pluggability of the module parsers.
column4: finish pluggability for par parsers

column3:
initial persistence for 
1) graph : process definitions & process executions
2) context : process variables
3) task management
column4: create initial persistence for graph, context and taskmgmt

column3: implement the scheduler functionality + a simple servlet that acts as a cron-task to check for due jobs on regular intervals.
column4: scheduler

column3: previously i didn't know that persistent objects could be used as keys in maps.  since that is possible, i have to revise the context implementation and perhaps some other situations where i used tectual reference to model objects.
column4: change the keys of maps to persistent objects where appropriate

column3:
Create a separate node type EndNode in org.jbpm.state.def
(add config parameter to support both end-token and end-process-instance)

Remove the method isEndNode from Node
column4: make end node a separate node

column3:
the jpdl conversion should be a standalone program that converts processdefinition.xml files and process archives from version 2 to version 3.  the way i think this is done the easiest is with dom4j : 
1) parse the old xml version to a dom tree
2) modify the dom tree to reflect the new version
3) write the modified dom tree to an xml file.

in a first iteration, conversion of the processdefinition.xml file is the easiest.  then in a second iteration, the file handling for process archives could be added.
column4: process conversion tool: jbpm2 to jbpm3
jbpm training preview of version 3
jbpm training process modelling and compatibility
jbpm training web interface
jbpm training other responsibilities
jbpm training state responsibility
jbpm training introduction and process development
create jbpm training

column3: For assigning issues we should devide jBPM into components.
column4: Add components to JIRA

column3: While testing with template-network.sf, crashes were observed after the test were finished and template was about to copy logs and configuration files for httpd node. These crashes are caused by mod_jk.log file, which can grow to ~450 MB.\nThis is currently solved by not copying mod_jk.log file. The goal of this JIRA is to find a way to backup mod_jk.log file as well.
column4: Archivation of all httpd logs, including mod_jk.log which can grow too large

column3:
I have several unexpected errors and failures with JDK7 a Webservices testsuite.

JDK7 comes with jaxws 2.2, but we must support jaxws 2.1 in EAP 5.x

- jaxws-api.jar must be endorsed. 
- this applies to both WS stacks - Native and CXF.


This issue is release blocker.

@Martha
For details see email thread "jbossws-native 3.1.12 building error with repository", you were in cc (July 10, 2012).
column4: jaxws-api.jar is not endorsed, WS errors on JDK7

column3:
When redeploying a .ear or .war containing .jsps, there are many situations causing a .jsp that needs to be recompiled to not be recompiled, or to be recompiled continuously.  

Any situation causing the timestamp of the modified .jsp to be older than the timestamp of its compiled class will cause it not to be recompiled; for example:
- reverting to a previous version of the .jsp using a version control
- timezone difference between development and production server
- .jsp never visited in production server until after change is made, which can happen for a rarely visited page, or a newly deployed server.
column4: .jsp fails to recompile after context redeployment

column4: I am migrating from jboss 4.3 to 5.1.1 eap and migrating from seam 2.1.2 to seam 2.2.4

column3:
95) 15. HTTP Session State Replication
Has no orienting material before launching into definitions, which is pretty alienating for the reader. Some introductory material would be nice. Or at least move the definitions into a Terms section so it's clearly separated. :\nMost instances of "load balancer" in this section need to be hyphenated.

96) IMPORTANT: 15. HTTP Session State Replication
"Session Persistence -- A client session that is exclusively allocated to a single server instance." No. You're talking about a general concept, not a specific session here. The definition given is for a persistent session. Removing the word "that" from this sentence would reduce clarity, but also mean that the sentence was more likely to be interpreted correctly. Similarly, it is a 'persistent session' not 'session persistence' that is typically referred to as a sticky session.

97) 15. HTTP Session State Replication
"...but not configuring web applications for session replication allows you to..." --> add comma after replication to aid clarity

98) 15.1 Enabling Session Replication in your application
Sub-headings or a variablelist might help people find the particular parameters they are looking for if they choose to skim the document.

99) 15.1 Enabling Session Replication in your application
"in the absence of a setAttribute call the container" --> add comma after call

100) 15.1 Enabling Session Replication in your application
"...even if its content has not been modified but simply accessed." --> ... even if its content has only been accessed, and not modified.

101) 15.1 Enabling Session Replication in your application
Enterprise Application Platform 5 --> JBoss Enterprise Application Platform 5 (and possibly also EWP5? can't remember if it's compatible)

102) 15.1 Enabling Session Replication in your application
"the granularity of what gets replicated" <-- a little awkward

103) 15.1 Enabling Session Replication in your application
"but since all attributes values" --> attributes'

104) 15.1 Enabling Session Replication in your application
(e.g. a Person object in the "husband" attribute sharing with another Person in the "wife" attribute a reference to an Address object). --> (for example, a Person object in the "husband" attribute sharing a reference to an Address object with another Person object in the "wife" attribute).

105) 15.1 Enabling Session Replication in your application
"The default value is standard-session-cache" --> missing full stop. Following sentence needs web-tier instead of web tier.

106) 15.1 Enabling Session Replication in your application
<replication-field-batch-mode> -- why is setting it to false not advised?

107) 15.2 HttpSession Passivation and Activation
HttpSessions passivation <-- HttpSession

108) 15.2.1 Configuring HttpSession Passivation
"is configured via the jboss-web.xml" <-- just configured in, not via

109) 15.2.1 Configuring HttpSession Passivation
max-active-session <-- XML example says this is max-active-sessions
number of sessions managed by the the session manager <-- remove a the

110) 15.2.1 Configuring HttpSession Passivation
"the web.xml session-timeout setting" <-- with both web.xml and session-timeout styled the same way, they blend together. maybe "the session-timeout setting in web.xml"

111) 15.2.1 Configuring HttpSession Passivation
The para immediately following the itemizedlist should be moved into the max-active-session list item. A separate section may be needed to discuss buddy replication (or just refer people to the clustering section of the admin guide)
"other nodes will also depend on" <-- rather than depend on, perhaps 'be affected by', or swap the sentence around so you can just say 'will also affect'

112) IMPORTANT: 15.3 Configuring the JBoss Cache instance used for session state replication
Please, god, get rid of all of those notes. None of those actually needs to be in an admonition. There are like six in a row with nearly identical text. Just scroll until you hit the striping.

113) 15.3 Configuring the JBoss Cache instance used for session state replication
"...refer to Deployment Via the CacheManager..." <-- Deployment Via is a street in Italy. lowercase via please.

114) 16. Using Clustered Single Sign-on
"...whether or not they are deployed on that same machine or on another node in the cluster." <-- ... regardless of whether they are...

115) 16.1 Configuration
mbean --> MBean

116) IMPORTANT: 16.1 Configuration
A positive value for this attribute allows proper handling of shutdown of a node that is the only one that had handled any of the sessions associated with an SSO. <-- This is not a good sentence.

117) 16.1 Configuration
SSO's <-- NO. SSOs.
requireReauthentication section has "true" instead of <literal>true</literal>, and seems to be missing 'for' after Realm in the following sentence: If "true", this Valve uses cached security credentials (username and password) to reauthenticate to the JBoss Web security Realm each request associated with an SSO session.

118) 16.3 Limitations
container managed authentication --> container-managed authentication
Also, this bullet needs a closing full stop.

119) 16.4 Configuring the Cookie Domain
"suppose we have a case where two apps, parenthetical statement, that wish" <-- remove 'that' after parenthetical statement

120) 16.4 Configuring the Cookie Domain
The programlisting has strange tabbing; move the cookieDomain attribute back to be in line with the start of the className attribute.

121) 17. Complete Working Example
Proxy Server example has an opening < that probably shouldn't be there

122) Appendix: workers.properties Reference
What exactly does a range of _ to / comprise?
"The structure of a Worker Property is worker.worker_name.directive" <-- missing final full stop

123) Appendix: workers.properties Reference -- workers.properties Connection Directives
"For example, a correct directive flag set is worker.node1.ping_mode=CI" <-- missing full stop, and should probably describe what it is attempting to set for clarity's sake

124) Appendix: workers.properties Reference -- workers.properties Load Balancing Directives
"...three times the load than other workers..." <-- three times the load OF other workers

125) Appendix: Java Properties Reference -- B.1. Proxy Configuration
itemizedlist is incorrectly punctuated
Proxy Configuration Values <-- not values, parameters or attributes
The default values are displayed next to the parameter name here, but nowhere else in the document.

126) Appendix: Java Properties Reference -- B.1. Proxy Configuration
"an usable worker" <-- a usable worker

127) Appendix: Java Properties Reference -- B.1. Proxy Configuration
cping and cpong or CPing and CPong? Consistency required.
column4: Part V Feedback for HTTP Connectors Guide

column3:
Part IV
--------

90) 13. What Is Netscape Server API
Question mark? lower case "is"
"to gain a basic understand about" --> "to gain a basic understanding of"
web server or HTTP Server? pick a term

91) 13. What Is Netscape Server API
Itemizedlist is not punctuated correctly -- closing full stop with no commas or semi-colons

92) 14. Configuring the NSAPI Connector on Solaris
worker node and master node use different cases here than in other places in the document

93) Task: Configure Initial Clustering Behaviour
What is non-initial clustering behaviour? >_>
Also, Step 1 -- perhaps say "disable the mappings ..... by commenting them out, as shown...". Basic, but helps clarify the task for the unfamiliar.

94) Task: Configure a Basic Cluster with NSAPI
"The procedure specifies [that] worker01..."
column4: Part IV Feedback for HTTP Connectors Guide

column3:
Part III
---------

59) 11. Overview
Read this chapter to get a brief <-- Read this chapter for a brief

60) 11.1 What is Internet Server API
Inconsistent punctuation in the list; if you're going to end with a full stop, you need to have ", and" or "; and" at the end of the first bullet

61) 11.1 What is Internet Server API
Usage of first person seems jarring; this is generally not the style used in the rest of the book.

62) 11.1 What is Internet Server API
"The DLLs are registered with the web server which makes them available to use." --> "These DLLs must then be registered with the web server before they are available for use."

63) 12.1 Prerequisites and Configuration Assumptions
Why is this a massive section, but most preprequisites in the first half of the book are as tiny little formalparas? Consistency please. :(

64) 12.1 Prerequisites and Configuration Assumptions
The IMPORTANT note should probably be integrated into the steps rather than at the beginning of the chapter. (Which I think ought to be Step 4 of 12.2.)

65) 12.2 Configure Server Instance as a Worker Node -- Prerequisites
Step 1 -- specifies use of the default profile. Is this the only profile supported? If so, remove "you want to configure as a worker node". If it's not the only supported profile, then the directive to copy default profile specifically should be removed. You can use default as an example after the main directive. Same again for subsequent steps -- I'd make a main directive that summarizes what they are doing and why, followed by a specific example.

66) Task: Define ISAPI Filter
Not immediately clear what the filter will do or why you are defining it. Screenshots would be nice, if anyone has licensed products around.

67) Task: Define ISAPI Filter
Master Server or Master server? Be consistent.

68) Task: Define ISAPI Filter -- Step 5
Is the location of the executable always C:\connectors\jboss-ep-5.1
ative\sbin\isapi_redirect.dll?

69) Task: Define ISAPI Virtual Directory
Not immediately clear why this needs to be done. Perhaps a summary of the configuration required at the beginning of Ch. 12 would be useful to orient people.

70) Task: Define ISAPI Virtual Directory -- Step 1
Missing closing full stop.

71) Task: Define ISAPI Virtual Directory -- Step 2
Again, is this ALWAYS the path?

72) Task: Define ISAPI Virtual Directory -- Step 4
Missing full-stop.

73) Task: Define ISAPI Web Service Extension
Bleh @ difference in cases between a button and a window -- I'm assuming this is present in the software, but still. :(

74) Task: Define ISAPI Web Service Extension -- Step 2
Missing "exactly as written" used in previous procedures. Also, is this always the path?

75) 12.4 Microsoft IIS 7 Initial Clustering Configuration -- Terms
URL at the end of the definition is not a hyperlink. Also, why does only this chapter have a Terms section?

76) Task: Define a JBoss Native ISAPI Restriction -- Step 1
"Start --> Run, then type inetmgr." <-- I think you also need to hit Enter or click Run afterward.

77) IMPORTANT: Task: Define a JBoss Native ISAPI Restriction -- Step 2
Ends abruptly. Opens in the what?

78) Task: Define a JBoss Native ISAPI Restriction -- Step 5
Is this always the path? Also, the spacing around the "jboss" value is too wide (spaces inside and outside the tag?).

79) Task: Define an JBoss Native Virtual Directory
s/an/a

80) Task: Define an JBoss Native Virtual Directory -- Step 2
Missing full stop after (exactly as written). Is this path always the same?

81) Task: Enable the ISAPI-dll Handler -- Step 1
Ends abruptly.

82) Task: Enable the ISAPI-dll Handler -- Step 4
Missing full stop.

83) Task: Configure ISAPI to serve a Basic Cluster -- Step 1
Double spacing around the directory. Append to, not append into.

84) Task: Configure ISAPI to serve a Basic Cluster -- Step 2
"... has an abstract directory name containing images" --> "has an abstract directory name, and contains images"

85) Task: Configure ISAPI to serve a Basic Cluster -- Step 3 & 4
Append to, not into.

86) Task: Configure ISAPI to serve a Basic Cluster -- Step 6
Is there a default location for the log_file property? We should tell people this. Also, tell them what exactly they are meant to be "verifying" about the logs.

87) Task: Configure ISAPI to serve a Load Balancing Cluster
Load-Balancing

88) Task: Configure ISAPI to serve a Load Balancing Cluster -- Step 1
Directory has extra spaces around it

89) Task: Configure ISAPI to serve a Load Balancing Cluster -- Step 3 & 4
Append to, not into.
column4: Part III Feedback for HTTP Connectors Guide

column3:
Part II
-------

When you refer to "the JBoss HTTP Connector mod_cluster", either use parenthetical commas or parentheses.

23) 4. Overview
reduced configuration --> reduced-configuration
utilizing --> using, it is not "using efficiently" it is just using it lol

24) 4.1 Key Features
"makes intelligent decisions on" --> makes intelligent decisions about

25) 4.2. Components -- Proxy Server
Shared Memory Manager (Module?) -- the rest of the modules listed have Module after their names. There are varying methods of capitalizing these in the section; please review for consistency. (Recommend removing Module from the last three modules and not capitalizing 'module'.)

26) 4.2 Components
Difference between "Proxy Server" and "Worker node components" both in capitalization and in the level of detail in the titles; please coordinate.

27) 4.2 Components
life cycle events --> life-cycle events according to our Word Usage Guide
(also occurs elsewhere in the document, do grep or rpl)

28) 5. Install Proxy Server Components
JBoss HTTP Connector mod-cluster <-- mod_cluster is used elsewhere, review for consistency

29) 5.1.1. mod_manager.so
"uses this location for generated keys" <-- uses this location to store generated keys, perhaps,to avoid for-for confusion

30) 5.1.1. mod_manager.so
Are there any limits on Maxcontext, Maxnode, Maxhost, Maxsessionid parameters?

31) 5.1.1. mod_manager.so
images/mod_status.png <--could stand to go inside a <figure> tag with a title, since it is all white it just kinda makes the spacing in the document look weird.

32) 5.1.2. mod_proxy_cluster.so
Again, keep an eye on case in your module names.
"to change load balancing behaviour" --> load-balancing

33) 5.1.3. mod_advertise.so
case in module names
"If port is not specified, the default port specified is 23364." --> the default port used, not specified

34) 5.2 Install Proxy Server Components
"on a JBoss Enterprise Web Server." <-- on a server instance, or on JBoss etc. not on a JBoss etc.

35) 5.2 Install Proxy Server Components
"The Native components are Operating System and processor architecture specific." --> The native components are specific to particular operating systems and processor architectures. (Either that or you need to hyphenate in a complicated way.)
Also, check caps on Native Components.

36) Task: Install Proxy Server Components
"Edit the JBoss Enterprise Web Server Apache configuration file" --> Edit the [Apache] configuration file in your JBEWS instance: JBOSS_EWS_DIST/httpd/conf/httpd.conf
Instruction for commenting out the line could be clearer, too.
(Question for the devs: is there anything the mod_proxy_balancer module *is* compatible with, and if not, why is it here?)

37) 6. Configure Basic Proxy Server
"to configure a JBoss Enterprise Web Server" --> again, _a_ JBEWS _instance_, or just JBEWS.
Also, "JBoss HTTP connector mod_cluster" is poorly marked up and capitalized in the opening here.

38) IMPORTANT: Task: Configure a Proxy Server Listener
Step 2 XML syntax highlighting is broken.

39) Task: Configure a Proxy Server Listener
Step 2, "Where IP_ADDRESS and PORT_NUMBER are the values from the Listen directive." --> s/are/match

40) IMPORTANT: Task: Configure a Proxy Server Listener
Step 3 last paragraph seems to contradict the final sentence in 6.1. Basic Proxy Configuration Overview "Server Advertisement" formalpara.

41) Task: Install and Configure a JBoss Enterprise Application Platform Worker Node
Inconsistent markup of jvmRoute attribute

42) Task: Install and Configure a JBoss Enterprise Application Platform Worker Node -- Step 5
"For Linux users" is not followed by advice for any other user.

43) Task: Install and Configure a JBoss Enterprise Application Platform Worker Node -- Important Box in Step 5
"JBoss Clustering relies on the UDP (User Datagram Protocol) multi-casting provided by jGroups." <-- multi-casting is elsewhere written as "multicast"; pick one and stick with it

44) Task: Install and Configure a JBoss Enterprise Application Platform Worker Node -- Important Box in Step 5
Inconsistent indentation of commands in the screen tag
Also, there seem to be two save operations in that set of commands... not sure those are both supposed to be there

45) Task: Install and Configure a JBoss Enterprise Web Server Worker Node
Appendix B, Java Properties Reference is only mentioned in the EWS worker note config section, but the opening of this Appendix suggests that it refers to JBEAP, not JBEWS. Which is it? And should this appear in the previous task's prerequisites as well?

46) 8. Further Server Configuration feels like a bit of a "misc" section. Can this content go elsewhere?

47) Task: Configure Application Platform Worker Node with Static Proxy List
comma separated --> comma-separated

48) 9.2 Clustered Node Operation
"The JBoss HTTP Connector can operate in non-clustered or clustered mode." --> in either clustered or non-clustered mode

49) IMPORTANT: 9.2 Clustered Node Operation
Does not include details on configuring clustered/non-clustered operation.

50) 10. Load Balancing Demonstration
jboss-eap-5.1/mod_cluster/demo directory.
Only in 5.1? I imagine this will need to be edited in future; may as well make it multi-version compliant now.

51) 10. Load Balancing Demonstration
I think QE likes us to avoid letting applications possess things (load-demo.war's)

52) 10. Load Balancing Demonstration
"Load-demo app" <-- decide how you will refer to the app and use it consistently; avoid swapping between this and load-demo.war
Similarly, decide whether to refer to it as the Demonstration or the Demo

53) 10.1 Set up the Demonstration
Step 2 Note -- text and admonition weight (note vs important) should match the admonition in the previous section, if this note is here at all.

54) 10.1 Set up the Demonstration
Step 3 - just prefix the step name with "Tomcat 6 only" or something, remove the admonition

55) 10.1 Set up the Demonstration
Step 3 - "<web-app>element," <-- missing space, and element not marked up as I would expect
Also, is it actually "appending" (that is, is </web-app> the last thing in the file before you add this)?

56) Task: Configure Client Control Tab Fields
"...to learn the values you must supply in the Client Control tab of the Load Balancing Demonstration." <-- 'complete this task to learn' is a vague task goal; what does the task actually accomplish?
I would recommend making Step 2 "Supply values for <required fields> and, optionally, <optional fields>." Move your list of references outside the task -- either beforehand with "the demo client requires a number of values, defined here" or after with "the fields in step two expect values as defined in the following list".

57) Task: Interact with the Demonstration
Task Prerequesites <-- differs from the straight "Prerequisites" in all other sections, and is misspelled

58) Task: Interact with the Demonstration
I'm not sure "experiment" should be a task/procedure.
Additionally, screenshots couldn't go amiss.
column4: Part II Feedback for HTTP Connectors Guide

column3:
Part I
------

7) 1. Overview
"takes the load of the disabled node" <-- reads like a typo for 'takes the load off'; awkward

8) 1. Overview
"Two distinct functions must be performed" <-- by...? Try "This involves two distinct operations:"

9) IMPORTANT: 1. Overview
"Sessions state replication" --> "Session state replication"
"is handled by JBoss at the application level" <-- if it's handled at the application level, it's not handled by JBoss. Perhaps this should say "on an application by application basis"? Or does JBoss delegate responsibility to the application?

10) 1. Overview
"A cost effective way of managing load-balancing is..." <-- hyphenation is wrong. cost-effective and load balancing, please

11) 1. Overview
"Apache httpd " <-- described previously as Apache httpd Server, pick one and stick with it

12) 2. Download and Install
"Apache httpd is included..." <-- described previously as Apache httpd Server, pick one and stick with it

13) 3. Configure load balancing using Apache and mod_jk
"Apache" <-- described previously as both Apache httpd Server and Apache httpd, pick one and stick with it, or say "hereafter referred to as Apache"
(Last time I will mention this unless it develops a new reference; it's running rife throughout the document.)

14) STYLE: 3. Configure load balancing using Apache and mod_jk -- Prerequisites
The weighting of the Task header and the Prerequisites header is the same, which makes it look like the steps actually belong to the Prerequisites.

15) 3. Configure load balancing using Apache and mod_jk -- Task: Configure Apache to Load mod_jk 
"...add a single line at the end of the file." <-- you then give an example that is not a single line.

16) 3. Configure load balancing using Apache and mod_jk -- Task: Configure Apache to Load mod_jk 
Really don't like the Important and Notes coming before the config file in step three. I don't think you need IMPORTANT or NOTE here, just tell them that they need to provide paths for these things.
You also assume people know what a directive is.
It might be best to split this step into the various segments of the configuration file, and provide a complete example config file as an appendix. For example:
<screen># Load mod_jk module
# Specify the filename of the mod_jk lib
LoadModule jk_module modules/mod_jk.so</screen>
The <literal>LoadModule</literal> directive must reference ... etc.

17) 3. Configure load balancing using Apache and mod_jk -- Task: Configure Apache to Load mod_jk 
"...use the JkMountFile directive to specify a mount points configuration file." --> missing apostrophe, mount point's

18) 3. Configure load balancing using Apache and mod_jk -- Task: Configure Apache to Load mod_jk 
"Specify the URL to forward..." --> Specify the URL whose requests should be forwarded... ?
"...and the worker name" --> and the name of the worker node you want to handle those requests ?

19) 3.1. Configure Worker Nodes in mod_jk
round robin --> round-robin?

20) 3.1. Configure Worker Nodes in mod_jk
"Append the following information into" --> append to, not into

21) 3.2 Configuring JBoss to work with mod_jk
jvmRoute isn't marked up at all

22) 3.2 Configuring JBoss to work with mod_jk
Note refers to community content.
Additionally, the URL displayed in the document is not the URL that the link resolves to.
column4: Part I Feedback for HTTP Connectors Guide

column3:
Front Matter
------------

1) Subtitle: remove "the" from before JBEAP

2) Author Group: Red Hat or Red Hat, Inc. for each author's company? Make a choice and stick with it.

3) Abstract: reads awkwardly, uses acronyms and short names before they are explained. Try:
...to install and configure the supported HTTP connectors  for use with JBEAP and JBEWS. This guide covers the Apache Tomcat Connector (mod_jk), JBoss HTTP Connector (mod_cluster), Internet Server API (ISAPI) and Netscape Server API (NSAPI), and discusses clustering and load-balancing with regard to each.

4) File Name Conventions:
Examples of paths that each keyword replaces would probably be useful.
"Each convention is styled differently to help you identify them" --> No, they are all styled the same way - just not as regular text.
"for Solaris 9 x86 or SPARC 64: /opt/SUNWwbsrv61" <-- missing trailing slash (or Solaris 10 version has an extra trailing slash)

5) Pull-quote Conventions
I know this isn't an issue with this guide, but it is an issue in general: "mono-spaced roman" is not displayed in mono-spaced roman, but in mono-spaced bold. Might be better off using <code> tag to simulate screen and programlisting output style, there.

6) 3.2 Give us Feedback
URL to bugzilla fills in template incorrectly: "Bug in HTTP Connectors Load Balancing Guide Guide" in summary line
column4: Front Matter Feedback for HTTP Connectors Guide

column3:
General:
--------

Load balancing and load-balancing are not interchangeable. Load balancing is the act of balancing load. A server that balances load, or has its load balanced, however, is a load-balancing server.

You may want to make the move to sentence case for titles, purely because so many JBoss products are randomly lower-case that if you attach them to an upper-case verb it just looks bizarre. The other way around is not as jarring.

Also, try not to use a Procedure title immediately after a section title... it looks strange to go straight from large to small font without any intervening explanation.

Not all replaceable values are marked up as such, which can confuse readers as to what should be entered literally, and what should be replaced with their own values. They're usually named well to avoid this confusion, but in the event that people actually read our style details, they will be confused.

Decide whether you are using "the file _____" or "the _____ file". It flip-flops throughout the document.

Be consistent about using punctuation at the end of list items, and at the end of step titles.

Avoid using e.g. and i.e. -- use for example and in effect instead.
column4: General Feedback for HTTP Connectors Guide

column3:
I always try installing the Enterprise Platform when a new release goes out, and I've found a minor issue in the Installer again. 

The link on the release notes page dumps you to the basic docs.redhat.com site splash page.

The fixes I would suggest are as follows:

Ideal: 
* Change the link for each release of the installer to the version of the release notes applicable to that release. 
* The name used for Release Notes is consistent between releases. For example, the last Release Note names were "Release Notes 5.1.0" and "Release Notes 5.1.1"
* You can always verify the link on http://documentation-stage.bne.redhat.com/docs/en-US/JBoss_Enterprise_Application_Platform/5/html-single/Release_Notes_5.1.1/index.html

Less Ideal: 
* Change the link behind the "Click here" hyperlink to "http://docs.redhat.com/docs/en-US/JBoss_Enterprise_Application_Platform/5/index.html"
* This is the EAP 5 splash page, that lists all docs including release notes.
* It would require less maintenance, but means the user must click once more to see the Release Notes.

I'll leave it up to you to determine the solution you feel would work better here.

Cheers

Jared

Add MySQL database connection support to JBoss EAP

column3:
We have an error of 

Caused by: org.jboss.xb.binding.JBossXBRuntimeException: {urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0}interceptor not found as a child of {urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0}bind in unordered_sequence: {urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0}alias* {urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0}install* {urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0}create? {urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0}property* {urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0}incallback* {urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0}start? {urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0}uninstall* {urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0}uncallback* {urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0}annotation* {urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0}constructor? {urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0}demand* {urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0}depends* {urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0}supply* {urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0}classloader? {choice}*

using this 

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<aop  xmlns="urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0">
     <bind pointcut="execution(public !static * $instanceof{com.data.dataaccess.DataAccessBase}->*(..))>
            <interceptor class="com.demo.SimpleInterceptor" /> 
       </bind>
     <bind pointcut="execution(public !static * $instanceof{com.service.MPService}->*(..))>
            <interceptor class="com.demo.SimpleInterceptor" /> 
       </bind>
</aop>


It works after changing to this.  

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<aop  xmlns="urn:jboss:aop-beans:1.0">
<interceptor name="SimpleInterceptor" class="com.demo.SimpleInterceptor"/>
    <bind pointcut="execution(public !static * $instanceof{com.data.dataaccess.DataAccessBase}->*(..))>
        <interceptor-ref name="SimpleInterceptor" />
    </bind>
    <bind pointcut="execution(public !static * $instanceof{com.service.MPService}->*(..))>
        <interceptor-ref name="SimpleInterceptor" />
    </bind>
</aop>

The misleading doc is located here: 
http://docs.redhat.com/docs/en-US/JBoss_Enterprise_Application_Platform/5/html/Administration_And_Configuration_Guide/ch 08s03.html

column3:
Hi Howard,
there is a problem with MaxRetry attribute. When it's set to -1 then consumer won't close when server is disconnected from DB. Client should get an exception and be reconnected to another node if he's using "ClusteredConnectionFactory". In this case it would broke HA.

This problem occured when testing patch from JBPAPP-5841 and fixed in JBPAPP-6058.

Thanks,

Mirek
column4: Document - consumer.close() method should not depend on MaxRetry attribute when trying to read messages from a node which is disconnected from DB

"JavaSE 6 includes support for JAX-WS, Version 2.1. Before starting your server, you need replace the APIs included in JDK 6 with the JBossWS jars by simply copying the following jars to ${JBOSS_HOME}/lib/endorsed from ${JBOSS_HOME}/server/production/lib:

column3:
In Section 6.1.1.17 of the "Administration and configuration guide",
(http://docs.redhat.com/docs/en-US/JBoss_Enterprise_Application_Platform/5.0/html-single/JBoss_Messaging_User_Guide/index.html#conf.serverpeer.attributes )
there is :
(a) no information on how to configure JBM SuckerPassword.

I found several forum post and Jira ticket but no documentation that explain how to do this task in Jboss wiki.
* User JBM.SUCKER is NOT authenticated  ( http://community.jboss.org/message/524686#524686 )
* Post install config incorrect: JBM Suckerpassword section (https://jira.jboss.org/browse/JBPAPP-4550)
and that this step is maybe already in Jboss EAP 4.x documentation :
* Add JBM Suckerpassword change to the installation guide. ( https://jira.jboss.org/browse/JBPAPP-451)
 

After this text 
" 6.1.1.17. SuckerPassword
JBoss Messaging internally creates connections between nodes to redistribute messages between clustered destinations. These connections are created with a special, reserved username. This attribute defines the password to use when creating these connections.
For versions of JBoss Messaging later than 1.4.1.GA, you must define the SuckerPassword on the SecurityMetadataStore.
Warning
The SuckerPassword must be changed at install time, or the default password will be used, giving any user who knows the default password access to any destination on the server. "


Can you add the following lines in  "Administration and configuration guide" :
If you want to configure JBM ( JBoss Messaging) suckerPassword, 

edit the file jboss-as/server/PROFILE/deploy/messaging/messaging-jboss-beans.xml
and
replace the line
<!-- <property name="suckerPassword">CHANGE ME!!</property> -->
by
<property name="suckerPassword">YOUR_PASSWORD</property>

and
edit the file jboss-as/server/PROFILE/deploy/messaging/messaging-service.xml
and uncomment the line
<attribute name="SuckerPassword"></attribute>
and
replace this line by
<attribute name="SuckerPassword">YOUR_PASSWORD</attribute>

where YOUR_PASSWORD parameter is the password that you choose for your Jboss server
and where PROFIL is the profile name for your Jboss server as all, production, default or standard.

Note : works fine with Jboss EAP 5.0.1 , but there is maybe some problem with Jboss EAP 5.1.0 :
Configuring JBM ( JBoss Messaging) suckerPassword do not work with Jboss EAP 5.1.x ( https://jira.jboss.org/browse/JBPAPP-5147)
column4: Configuring JBM ( JBoss Messaging) suckerPassword is missing in EAP 5.x's "Administration and configuration guide"

The class org.jboss.seam.transaction.EjbSynchronizations violates the Java-Specs.

<!-- ********************* deploy/ejb3-connectors-service.xml **************** -->
 <!-- EJB3 wants to have the service create its own ServiceBinding object

but there is no deploy/ejb3-connectors-service.xml file in Jboss EAP 5.0.x ,

Please replace the lines
<!-- ********************* deploy/ejb3-connectors-service.xml **************** -->
.... 
dynamically.  See the value-factory usage in deploy/ejb3-connectors-service.xml -->
with the new lines
<!-- ********************* deploy/ejb3-connectors-jboss-beans.xml **************** -->
... 
dynamically.  See the value-factory usage in deploy/ejb3-connectors-jboss-beans.xml -->
in the file 
conf indingservice.beans\META-INF indings-jboss-beans.xml

I have incorporated as much information as I can for the four blog posts.  Before I release the draft to the CC Team, could you please review my incorporations to ensure they are correct.  Because I'm not a Java developer, I need to ensure the terminology I'm using is correct.  

The sections I have added are:

http://hudson.qa.jboss.com/hudson/job/JBoss_EAP_Security_Guide-Daily_Build/lastSuccessfulBuild/artifact/JBoss_Security_Guide/target/docbook/publish/en-US/html_single/index.html#JBoss-Security-Configuring_Microcontainer_Security_Domains

Cheers

Jared

That directory does not exist in the JBoss distribution, and that URL does not have any examples available from it.
